Create a 4/4 snare drum pattern with the following characteristics.The pattern should begin with a grace note played with the left hand ('L'), followed by an eighth note on C5.Immediately after the grace note, play a quarter note with the right hand ('R') on the same pitch (C5).The rest of the measure consists of three quarter note rests, creating a rhythmic pause.Ensure the notation includes the correct clef (percussion), key signature (C major), and appropriate beaming for the eighth note.

    <score-part id=\"P1\">

    </score-part>
  </part-list>

        <pitch>
          <step>C</step>
          <octave>5</octave>
        </pitch>
        <duration>1</duration>
        <voice>1</voice>
        <type>eighth</type>
        <beam number=\"1\">begin</beam>
        <stem>up</stem>
        <lyric number=\"1\">
          <syllabic>single</syllabic>
          <text>L</text>
        </lyric>
      </note>
      <note>
        <pitch>
          <step>C</step>
          <octave>5</octave>
        </pitch>
        <duration>1</duration>
        <voice>1</voice>
        <type>quarter</type>
        <stem>up</stem>
        <lyric number=\"1\">
          <syllabic>single</syllabic>
          <text>R</text>
        </lyric>
      </note>
      <note>
        <rest />
        <duration>2</duration>
        <voice>1</voice>

      </note>

Create a 4/4 snare drum pattern consisting of two sets of single paradiddles, followed by two quarter note rests:The first paradiddle starts with a 16th note on C5, played with the right hand ('R'), followed by a 16th note on C5 with the left hand ('L'), another 16th note with the right hand ('R'), and a final 16th note with the right hand ('R'). These notes should be beamed together as a group.The second paradiddle immediately follows, starting with a 16th note on C5, played with the left hand ('L'), followed by a 16th note on C5 with the right hand ('R'), another 16th note with the left hand ('L'), and a final 16th note with the left hand ('L'). These notes should also be beamed together as a group. The measure concludes with two quarter note rests, providing a rhythmic pause. Create a snare drum rhythm in 4/4 time using a single stroke pattern in eighth notes. The rhythm should start on the C5 pitch in percussion clef. After the single strokes, the measure should end with two quarter-note rests.

<score-partwise version=\"3.1\">
